importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the report's publication reflects the latest developments in the ongoing conflict and North Korea’s involvement in the war in Ukraine.
The attack on Kherson occurred in September 2024, marking a key event where a North Korean submunition was discovered, indicating active material collaboration between North Korea and Russia.
North Korea began sending troops to Russia in the fall of 2024, with the first deployment noted in August 2024, signaling a significant escalation in North Korea’s military involvement in the war.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2024 to 2025 marks the peak of North Korean involvement in Russia’s war efforts, including troop deployments and weapon transfers, as shown by intelligence reports and recovered equipment.

keyTakeAways: A North Korean submunition was found in a drone used to attack Ukraine in September 2024.
The submunition was marked with Korean characters referencing the Juche calendar, indicating it was produced in Juche 89 (2000 CE).
The device was modified for use on a first-person-view drone using basic materials like wooden sticks, wire, and duct tape.
This discovery establishes a direct material link between North Korea’s defense industry and Russia’s military actions in Ukraine.
Russia has significantly ramped up drone attacks and production, using cheap, mass-produced drones to overwhelm Ukrainian air defenses.
North Korea has expanded its weapons program and sent approximately 12,000 troops to Russia since 2024, with about 4,000 reported killed or wounded.
The presence of North Korean technology in Ukraine suggests increased collaboration between Pyongyang and Moscow in the war effort.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A North Korean submunition, marked with Juche 89 (2000 CE), was discovered in a drone used to attack Kherson, Ukraine, in September 2024. The submunition, originally designed for rocket artillery, was modified for use on a first-person-view drone using basic materials. This discovery, reported by Conflict Armament Research (CAR), confirms a direct material link between North Korea’s defense industry and Russia’s war efforts in Ukraine. The finding underscores North Korea’s growing role in supporting Russia’s drone warfare campaign, which has intensified since 2024, including the deployment of around 12,000 North Korean troops to Russia, with about 4,000 reported killed or wounded.
title: North Korean submunition found in drone used to attack Ukraine, report finds
